title: Rosina Emmet Sherwood
text:
Rosina Emmet Sherwood (1854–1948) was an American painter.
Born in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>, she was the daughter of William J. and <a href="Julia%20Pierson%20Emmet">Julia Pierson Emmet</a>; her surviving siblings were <a href="Robert%20Temple%20Emmet">Robert Temple Emmet</a> (1854–1936), her twin; <a href="William%20LeRoy%20Emmet">William LeRoy Emmet</a> (1858–1941); <a href="Devereux%20Emmet">Devereux Emmet</a> (1861–1934); Richard Stockton Emmet (b.1863); <a href="Lydia%20Field%20Emmet">Lydia Field Emmet</a> (1866–1952); <a href="Jane%20Emmet%20de%20Glehn">Jane Emmet de Glehn</a> (1873–1961); <a href="C.%20Temple%20Emmet">Christopher Temple Emmet</a> (1868–1957); and Thomas Addis Emmet (b.1870). Her first cousin was the painter <a href="Ellen%20Emmet%20Rand">Ellen Emmet Rand</a>.
Sherwood may have received her earliest training in art from her mother; a sketchbook dating to 1873 was in the hands of family members in 1987. Rosina traveled to Europe in 1876–1877, and was presented to <a href="Queen%20Victoria">Queen Victoria</a> during the trip. Returning to New York, she and her friend <a href="Dora%20Wheeler%20Keith">Dora Wheeler</a> began study with <a href="William%20Merritt%20Chase">William Merritt Chase</a>, and by 1881 she took studio space in the <a href="Tenth%20Street%20Studio%20Building">Tenth Street Studio Building</a>. Among her earliest works were illustrations for publications such as "<a href="Harper%27s%20Magazine">Harper's Magazine</a>", and in 1880 she won the $1,000 first prize in a competition to design a Christmas card for <a href="Louis%20Prang">Louis Prang</a> & Company. Sherwood and Wheeler worked together in the design firm Associated Artists, run by Candace Wheeler, Dora's mother; they designed tapestries, curtains, and wallpaper. Subjects included a variety drawn from American literature.
In 1884–1885 the women attended classes at the <a href="Acad%C3%A9mie%20Julian">Académie Julian</a> in Paris; Sherwood's instructor there was <a href="Tony%20Robert-Fleury">Tony Robert-Fleury</a>.
Rosina married, in 1887, Arthur Sherwood, having five children with him, including future <a href="Pulitzer%20Prize">Pulitzer Prize</a> winner <a href="Robert%20E.%20Sherwood">Robert E. Sherwood</a>. She continued working after her marriage, often looking to members of her family as her subjects. 
<a href="Elizabeth%20Eggleston%20Seelye">Elizabeth Eggleston Seelye</a>'s story "“The A.O.I.B.R." appeared in <a href="Harper%27s%20Bazaar">Harper's Bazaar</a> in 1889 with Sherwood's illustration of a child reading. The Rockwell Centre for American Visual Studies cites this as a surprisingly early illustration of a girl reading. The subject of a female reading in this sketch is thought as rare (like the examples in Louisa Allcott's <a href="Little%20Women">Little Women</a>).
A portrait of <a href="Archer%20Milton%20Huntington">Archer Huntington</a>, husband of <a href="Anna%20Hyatt%20Huntington">Anna Hyatt Huntington</a>, dated to 1892, is currently owned by the <a href="Hispanic%20Society%20of%20America">Hispanic Society of America</a>.
In 1893, Sherwood painted the mural "The Republic's Welcome to Her Daughters" for the <a href="The%20Woman%27s%20Building%20%28Chicago%29">Woman's Building</a> of the <a href="1893%20World%27s%20Fair">1893 World's Fair</a>. Her work was also <a href="List%20of%20women%20artists%20exhibited%20at%20the%201893%20World%27s%20Columbian%20Exposition">exhibited</a> in the <a href="Museum%20of%20Science%20and%20Industry%20%28Chicago%29">Palace of Fine Arts</a> at the Fair
She accepted commissions once more in 1918 to provide support for her family, and continued painting watercolors for much of her career. One of these, 1922's "San Pedro, Manila", was included in the inaugural exhibition of the <a href="National%20Museum%20of%20Women%20in%20the%20Arts">National Museum of Women in the Arts</a>, "American Women Artists 1830–1930", in 1987.
A drawing by Sherwood is currently in the collection of the <a href="Smithsonian%20American%20Art%20Museum">Smithsonian American Art Museum</a>.
